sub_title: Human being; assistant professor, medical physicist resident @UMC Utrecht; Art-lover; Deep learning in medical imaging for adaptive radiotherapy
summary:
Matteo is an assistant professor investigating adaptive radiotherapy, image acquisition/reconstruction, segmentation, and registration with deep learning in the Computational Imaging group, Radiotherapy Department, Center of Image Sciences, Imaging and Cancer division of UMC Utrecht.

Background
Matteo was born Como (Italy) in May 1989 and studied Physics at Insubria University, graduating cum laude in March 2014. In those years, he gained interest in experimental Physics, with a predilection for particle detectors. Following this interest, he had the opportunity to perform profilometry measurements of an anti-proton beam and measure the diameter of the Sun with a pixelated silicon detector and develop a detector for spectral measurements of neutrons produced by an in-hospital linear accelerator.
After getting in touch with the hospital environment and feeling the need to broaden his horizons, he decided to step into the field of medical imaging, where, by chance, detectors are somehow involved. From May 2014 to May 2018, he was enrolled as a PhD candidate at the Radiotherapy Department of the Universitair Medisch Centrum Utrecht (The Netherlands). During his PhD project, he had the luck to discover the beauty of magnetic resonance imaging in the practical realm of radiotherapy.
Since 2018, Matteo has been a Postdoc dedicating his efforts to translate deep learning for adaptive radiotherapy clinically. Since January 2022, he has been appointed assistant professor, gaining the opportunity to facilitate clinical translation further and keeping an eye on cutting-edge software and its integration and development in the healthcare continuum.
Nowadays, medical imaging and radiotherapy are still Matteo's passions.

profile_positions.description: Medical physicist resident, in Dutch "klinisch fysicus in opleiding" with focus on radiotherapy
profile_positions.title: Medical physicist resident

profile_positions.description:
Somewhere between research and clinic, let's call it clinical translation, focusing on developing and validating deep learning models for adaptive radiotherapy; you can think of the following applications: image synthesis, segmentation, reconstruction, and registration.

My ultimate goal: leverage information currently available for patients' sake. Always happy to find collaborators along this path.
profile_positions.title: Assistant Professor

profile_positions.description: In Magnetic Resonance(MR)-only radiotherapy, sole MR images are used for delineation, dose planning and as reference images for patient positioning during irradiation. However, MRI does not provide information to forecast the attenuation of radiation in the body, and it may suffer geometrical distortion impacting the accuracy of patient positioning. To overcome such challenges, this thesis investigated strategies to perform MRI-based prostate radiotherapy facilitating future clinical implementation. First, the thesis focused on the evaluation of the dosimetric accuracy obtainable during MR-based planning studies. Embracing the clinical perspective, the accuracy of MR-based dose calculation has been investigated using a commercially available solution for sCT generation. MR-based dose calculation for photon and proton radiotherapy was studied demonstrating its accuracy. Second, it was assessed whether image-guided radiotherapy (IGRT) is feasible when patient setup correction relies solely on MRI as a reference imaging modality. Considering that IGRT for prostate patients is based on gold fiducial marker implanted in the prostate. It has been evaluated the inter-observer localisation of the marker. Also, an automatic method has been proposed leading to a detection rate comparable to a manual observer. Ultimately, the work presented in this thesis contributed to shaping the clinical implementation of the MR-only pathway in Utrecht aiming at supporting a safe introduction of MR-only radiotherapy for prostate cancer patients.
